penguin.linux_kaio – The Linux-Specific Interface For Aync I/O¶

penguin.linux_kaio.io_setup()¶

create an iocontext object

Parameters:maxevents (int) – maximum number of events the iocontext will be capable of accepting
Returns:an iocontext object
class penguin.linux_kaio.iocontext¶
cancel()¶

attempt to cancel a previously submitted io operation

Parameters:index (int) – the index of the operation to cancel (this was returned by prep_read(), prep_write(), or prep_fsync())
destroy()¶

de-activate this iocontext object

getevents()¶

retrieve the results of io operations

Parameters:
  • max (int) – maximum number of results to return (defaults to the total number of operations in the context)
  • min (int) – minimum number of results to return (default 1)
  • timeout (int, float or None) – maximum time to block waiting for min events (default None for unlimited)
Returns:

a list with one entry for every completed io operation in the context, each located at the index that was returned from the prep_* method call

io operations might have a None result for any one of a number of reasons:

  • the operation’s result was returned in a previous getevents invocation
  • the operation wasn’t yet complete but min other operations were
  • the operation wasn’t yet complete and timeout expired
  • the operation was added after submit() was called
  • max other operations are also complete and have their results returned

the result type depends on the type of the original request:

read requests
a string of the data that was read
write requests
a nonnegative integer of the number of bytes written
fsync requests
True for success

all operation types can have negative numbers as a result, in that case it is -errno

prep_fsync()¶

set up an fsync operation on a file descriptor

Parameters:
  • fd (int) – the file descriptor to fsync
  • eventfd (int) – the eventfd to notify when the fsync has completed (default None for no notification)
Returns:

the integer index of this operation in the iocontext
prep_read()¶

set up a read operation on a file descriptor

Parameters:
  • fd (int) – the file descriptor from which to read
  • nbytes (int) –

    the number of bytes to read.

    if doing direct I/O (O_DIRECT set on the file descriptor), this will have to be a multiple of penguin.linux_kaio.ALIGN_TO

  • offset (int) –

    the position in the file from which to begin the read (default 0)

    if doing direct I/O (O_DIRECT set on the file descriptor), this will have to be a multiple of penguin.linux_kaio.ALIGN_TO

  • eventfd (int) – the eventfd to notify when the read is complete (default None for no notification)
Returns:

the integer index of this operation in the iocontext
prep_write()¶

set up a write operation on a file descriptor

Parameters:
  • fd (int) – the file descriptor to which to write
  • data (str) – the data to write to the file
  • offset (int) –

    the position in the file from which to start (over-)writing (default 0)

    if doing direct I/O (O_DIRECT set on the file descriptor), this will have to be a multiple of penguin.linux_kaio.ALIGN_TO

  • eventfd (int) – the eventfd to notify when the write is complete (default None for no notification)
Returns:

the integer index of this operation in the iocontext
submit()¶

submit all prepared operations on this iocontext

Returns:the number of io operations submitted
